questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the fungal cell wall?
questions.solution:
Chitin is a component of the fungal cell wall.

General characteristics of Fungi:

  • They are unicellular/multicellular eukaryotes.
  • The cell wall contains chitin, glucan, mannan and other polysaccharides.
  • The cytoplasmic membrane contains ergosterol.
  • They possess true nuclei with the nuclear membrane and paired chromosomes.
  • They divide sexually, asexually or by both.

Raymond Sabouraud is known as the Father of Mycology.

questions.text: Which of the following is a yeast?
questions.solution:
Cryptococcus is a yeast.

Option A: Candida is a yeast-like fungus.

Option C: Fusarium is a mold/filamentous fungus.

Option D: Talaromyces is a dimorphic fungus.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a sexual spore?
questions.solution:
Sporangiospore is not a sexual spore. It is an asexual spore.

Fungi can be classified into 4 classes based on sexual spore formation:

Class Sexual spore Asexual spore
Glomerulomycetes Oospores, Zygospores Sporangiospores
Ascomycetes Ascospores Conidia
Basidiomycetes Basidiospores Conidia
Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes) Yet to be identified Conidia

Fungi imperfecti (Deuteromycetes): These are the fungi whose sexual phases are yet to be identified. Most of the fungi of medical importance belong to this group.

Note: The earlier classification of Phycomycetes, under which Zygomycetes, Oomycetes, and other sub-phyla were present, is now obsolete. Phylum Glomerulomycota has replaced it.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on spore formation

It is classified into 4 types:

Glomeromycota:

  • Lower fungi with non-septate hyphae.
  • Asexual spores are called sporangiospores – within swollen sac-like structure called sporangia
  • Sexual spores are called zygospores and oospores

 

Ascomycota: 

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called ascospores - formed within a sac or ascus.

 

Basidiomycota:

  • Asexual spores are called conidia.
  • Sexual spores are called basidiospores (on a basidium or base).

 

Deuteromycetes: (fungi imperfecti or hypomycetes) – sexual stages yet to be discovered.

questions.text: Which of the following fungal spores are formed by condensation of the hyphal elements?
questions.solution:
Arthrospores are asexual spores that are formed along the mycelium/hyphae by segmentation and condensation of hyphae.

Arthrospores are commonly formed by dermatophytes, especially those belonging to the genus Trichophyton. They are also formed by dimorphic fungi like Coccidiodes sp.

questions.text: A young patient presents to the dermatology OPD with a history of itchy hypopigmented patches over her chest for 6 months. A KOH mount is prepared with the skin scraping sample, which on microscopy reveals a characteristic appearance as shown in the image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the KOH mount preparation showing the spaghetti and meatball appearance suggest pityriasis versicolor.

Pityriasis versicolor is a chronic superficial infection of the stratum corneum caused by Malassezia globosa and Malassezia furfur. The most common site involves the neck, chest, back, and upper arms. The lesions often appear as hypopigmented areas.

The KOH mount reveals fungal hyphae that are short and thick (like spaghetti or banana) and many variously sized spores (like meatballs or grapes) referred to as spaghetti and meatballs or bananas and grapes appearance.

Treatment includes topical azoles or terbinafine for 2 weeks.

The image below shows the hypopigmented lesions of P. versicolour over the chest.

Electron microscopic image of Malassezia furfur

questions.text: Which of the following statements about dermatophytes is true?
questions.solution:
Microsporum infects only skin and hair, not nails.

Dermatophytes include 3 genera:

  • Microsporum: It infects only hair and skin (not nails). The species included in this genus are-
    •  M. gypseum
    • M. canis
    • M. nanum.
  • Epidermophyton: It infects only skin and nails (not hair). E. floccosum is the only species in this genus.
  • Trichophyton: It infects skin, hair, and nails. The species falling under this genus are-
    • T. rubrum
    • T. mentagrophytes
    • T. tonsurans
    • T. schoenleinii
    • T. violaceum

questions.text: A 23-year-old-lady came to the dermatology clinic with complaints of hair loss and the presence of firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft as shown. There is no associated pruritis of the scalp. Which of the following could be the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The presence firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft is suggestive of black piedra. The causative agent of this condition is Piedraia hortae.

Piedra is a superficial fungal infection of the hair shaft. It is of two types:

  • Black piedra: It is characterized by firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules along the hair shaft. Scalp hair is most often affected. Hair becomes brittle and breaks easily leading to complains of hair loss. It is caused by Piedraia hortae.
  • White piedra: It is characterized by soft, white or light brown transparent nodules that are easily detached from the hair. It affects pubic, axillary, facial hair more commonly than scalp hair. It is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.

Management involves shaving or cutting off the affected hair along with topical antifungals.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presented with complaints of discoloration of his toenail for the past 4 months as shown in the image below. Which pathogen most commonly causes this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of onychomycosis and the pathogen most commonly causing this condition is Trichophyton rubrum. Diabetes increases the risk of onychomycosis.

Onychomycosis refers to nail infections caused by fungi. It can be due to dermatophytes, non-dermatophytic moulds, and candida. Tinea unguium refers to nail infections caused by dermatophytes. This condition may affect toenails or fingernails, but toenail infections are particularly common. 

The following photomicrograph of the nail segment in KOH shows T. rubrum fungal hyphae invading nail cells.

The following image is of a lactophenol cotton blue(LPCB) mount showing pyriform shaped microconidia on the hyphae of T. rubrum.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes disease following traumatic inoculation into the skin?
questions.solution:
Sporothrix schenckii causes infection followed by traumatic inoculation into the skin.

It is a dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation such as grasses, trees, rose bushes, etc. Following traumatic inoculation into the skin as in thorn prick, S schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous infection. This is usually further followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes as shown in the image below.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the most commonly used culture media for growing fungi?
questions.solution:
Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) is the most commonly used culture media for growing fungi. It does not contain taurocholate.

It consists of antibiotics like gentamicin or chloramphenicol to inhibit the contaminant bacteria and also cycloheximide to inhibit the growth of saprophytic fungi. It has an acidic pH of 5.4.

Media used in mycology can be classified as:

  • Specific media-
    • SDA agar
    • Czapek-Dox medium
    • Birdseed agar
    • Cornmeal agar
  • Non-specific media-
    • Blood agar
    • Brain heart infusion agar

questions.text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presented with multiple ulcerative eruptions along the lymphatics of his hand. A tissue biopsy was taken and sent for culture. Microscopic examination of the organism cultured is shown in the image. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The presence of multiple ulcerative eruptions along the lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis, caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It is a thermally dimorphic fungus that lives on vegetation.

The lesions occur following traumatic inoculation of the fungus. A granulomatous nodule is first formed at the site of inoculation that may progress to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. The infection can spread via lymphatic channels from the skin and subcutaneous tissue to the lymph nodes resulting in formation of secondary ulcers on the lymph nodes. This condition is known as lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. This disease is commonly encountered among gardeners, forest workers and manual labourers.

questions.text: A farmer developed multiple ulcerative nodules along the lymphatics following a rose thorn prick a week ago. Microscopic finding of the skin biopsy is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an asteroid body which is characteristically seen in a case of sporotrichosis.

Asteroid bodies are formed due to the deposition of the immune complexes around the yeast cell. It consists of a central rounded or oval basophilic, cigar-shaped yeast cell surrounded peripherally by eosinophilic radiations. Formation of such structures is called the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon.

Note: Asteroid bodies are also seen in sarcoidosis. Those are irregular, star-shaped inclusions seen in multinucleate giant cells.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics. 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

questions.text: A middle-aged man from south India presented to the OPD with a swelling in his left foot that is unresponsive to antibiotics. On examination, multiple discharging sinuses were noted. The discharge contained brown granules that were soft in consistency. Which of the following is likely the causative agent?
questions.solution:
A swelling with multiple discharging sinuses with brown granules that is unresponsive to the antibiotics is suggestive of eumycetoma caused by Madurella mycetomatis.

Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It can be divided into three types- eumycetomas, actinomycetomas and botryomycosis.

Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue from soil or vegetable sources. Within host tissues, the organisms develop to form compacted colonies (grains) 0.5–2 mm in diameter, the color of which depends on the organism responsible. It results in tumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging these grains or granules.

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • A. Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.
  • B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

Treatment:

The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma on the other hand, responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

Option A: Actinomadura madurae causes actinomycetoma which would respond to antibiotics.

Option B: Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis which is characterised by lesions along the route of lymphatics.

Option C: Fonsecaea pedrosoi causes chromoblastomycosis which would not have discharging sinuses.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dimorphic fungus?
questions.solution:
Pneumocystis jirovecii is a yeast-like fungus and not a dimorphic fungus.

Dimorphic fungi exist in the yeast form in body tissues and cultures maintained at 37°C, and in the filamentous form in cultures at room temperature(25°C).

Examples of dimorphic fungi include:

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis
  • Coccidioides immitis
  • Paracoccidioides brasiliensis
  • Talaromyces marneffei
  • Sporothrix schenckii
  • Histoplasma capsulatum
  • Coccidioides posadasii

  • Yeast-like
  • Molds

Yeast like:

  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man had  presented to the clinic with a history of chronic cough. His chest X-ray showed a mass in the left lung with hilar lymphadenopathy. Biopsy of the mass was done and findings are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the presence of tiny yeast forms within macrophages are suggestive of Histoplasmosis which is also called Darling's disease. Other names of this condition include Cave's disease and Ohio disease.

The causative agent is a dimorphic fungus called Histoplasma capsulatum. Transmission occurs via inhalation of conidia.

After inhalation, the conidia develop into yeast cells and are engulfed by alveolar macrophages. Within macrophages, the yeasts may disseminate to reticuloendothelial tissues, such as the liver, spleen, bone marrow, and lymph nodes.

Biopsy reveals tiny (2-4 microns) oval-shaped yeast cells inside macrophages.

On culture and microscopy, tuberculate macroconidia and hyaline septate mold with microconidia are seen.

It is treated using azole antifungals.

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy with a recent history of travel to South America was brought to the hospital with fever, enlarged lymph nodes and multiple skin lesions on his face. Tissue sample from the lesion shows the following findings under microscopy. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the characteristic pilot's wheel appearance on culture(image) is suggestive of paracoccidioidomycosis caused by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It is also called Lutz mycosis/ South American blastomycosis.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus that causes a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, lymph nodes. On culture, yeast form is seen at 37° C and the mycelial form at 25° C.

Microscopy of tissue sample reveals thick walled, round, yeast cells with numerous buds attached to each other circumferentially giving the classic mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

Most infections are asymptomatic and few individuals with acute disease present with hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy and skin lesions.

The below image shows skin lesions in a child with paracoccidioidomycosis.

Treatment:

  • Mild/moderate disease: Itraconazole
  • Severe disease: Amphotericin B for 2-3weeks followed by Itraconazole.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with low-grade fever and a skin lesion as shown below.  He had a  history of recent travel to North America.  Chest X-Ray reveals consolidation in the right lung with hilar lymphadenopathy. Culture on Sabouraud dextrose agar at 37°C shows thick-walled, large (7-20 µ), round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with pulmonary and cutaneous involvement along with a history of travel to North America and the characteristic culture findings suggests the diagnosis of Blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces dermitidis. 

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection, characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions, especially, in the lungs and skin.

It is most common in North America and so is also called North Amerian Blastomycosis.

The causative organism is a thermally dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in the soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

  1. Pulmonary disease:
    • Presents with cough, sputum production, chest pain, and fever
    • Hilar lymphadenopathy may be present
    • Focal or diffuse consolidation, miliary lesions, or abscess formation may occur.
    • Resembles TB and Histoplasmosis 
  2. Cutaneous disease:
    • Involvement of face and exposed parts of the skin
    • Skin lesion: ulcerated verrucous granulomas with an advancing border and central scarring. The border is filled with microabscesses and has a sharp, sloping edge. (image in stem)
  3. Disseminated disease:
    • Multiple skin lesions are the most common presentation
    • Highly fatal 
    • Genitourinary tract (especially prostate) is frequently involved
    • Bone involvement resembles chronic osteomyelitis.
It can be diagnosed based on culture findings. Characterictic findings include the presence of thick-walled round yeast cell with a single broad-based bud when cultured at 37°C. (figure of 8 appearance)

Treatment:

  • Localised mild/moderate disease - Itraconazole (6 months)
  • Disseminated/ severe disease - Amphotericin B

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A middle-aged man residing in a rural area presents with psychosis, ataxia and convulsions. On further inquiry, you find out there is history of similar complaints in the family members who recently consumed food prepared with grains as shown in the image. What is the poisoning is most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the presence of dark coloured ergot growing on the wheat as shown in the image are suggestive of ergotism due to Claviceps purpurea

Mycotic poisoning is of two types: Mycetism and Mycotoxicosis

Mycetism:

The fungus itself causes toxic effects.

Examples:

  • Claviceps → Ergot poisoning
  • Coprine → coprine poisoning
  • Inocybe → muscarine poisoning

Mycotoxicosis:

Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects.

Examples:

  • Aflatoxins: These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus.
  • Fusarium toxins
  • Citrinin toxin was first isolated from Penicillium citrinum.

questions.text: The below given image shows result of hair perforation test. The organism likely to show below given appearance is
questions.solution:
Image shows surface erosion of shaft caused by Trichophyton mentagrophytes.

Hair perforation test:

  • Done to differentiate Trichophyton rubrum from mentagrophytes.
  • Few strands of human hair are placed in a petridish with 20 ml of distilled water and autoclaved.
  • Few drops of sterile 10% yeast extract and a few fragments of the test fungus are added to the hair strands.
  • Incubated at 250C for 2-3 weeks.
  • Hair is removed and examined microscopically in a lactophenol cotton blue stained wet preparation.
  • T.mentagrophytes causes surface erosion of the shaft resulting in wedge shaped appearance of the shaft.
